The case of Alex Mitchell: who died while laughing at a television show, provides evidence of laughter potentially leading to fatal outcomes.
Mitchell: s death was caused by a heart rhythm disorder called Long QT syndrome, which can be triggered by instances of excitement or exertion.
Another incident in Bangkok: where an ice cream truck driver died while laughing in his sleep, suggests that laughter-induced heart attacks can occur even during rest.
Historical anecdotes: such as the death of Burmese king Nandabayin and the fictional demise of Pecos Bill, further support the claim that people have died from laughter.
